message: http://downloadsquad.switched.com/2011/02/07/firefox-4-5-6-and-7-to-be-released-before-the-end-of-2011/
version # inflation--
Reminds me of the winamp stunt. they skipped version 4 saying v2+v3 = v5.
I seem to recall a linux distro in the late 90's, early 00's doing the same.
@justinlilly slackware.

From wikipedia: In 1999, Slackware's release number jumped from 4 to 7. Patrick Volkerding explained this as a marketing effort to show that Slackware was as up-to-date as other Linux distributions, many of which had release numbers of 6 at the time, and Patrick expected them to reach version 7 by the time of the jump.
the winamp guys get a pass for anything though cause they did it for humor sake, and comon, it really whips the llama's ass
@asenchi I thought it was them, but couldn't find the reference in the first 3 google results.
When I first downloaded that in the 90's, I thought it said "lick"
I still, to this day, miss Winamp 2. 3 and 5 just sucked.
There's only one thing I miss from Winamp that iTunes does not have: a speed plugin.
Winamp had this plugin that would allow you to speed up songs up to 200% faster without a change in pitch, which was _so perfect_ for late night coding

I'd typically put Unreal Tournament - The Course on single-repeat at 150%, and gradually bump it up 10% faster every hour or so. By the time it hit 200% it was like having a load of caffeine in your system as the adrenaline just pumps like mad, and programming went sooooo smoothly :D
#1 is the idea of the playlist. When you pressed play on an album it added the album to the "current" playlist so you could drag new albums to play after the current one was done
*cough* amarok
I miss everything about Winamp
#2 is only using 1% of my CPU and like 80MB of ram as opposed to half my machine with iTunes
foobar2000 had some nice play order management too (at least with a “queue this to play next” plugin i wrote)
Yeah, if you use Windows, Foobar2000 is pretty amazing.
Basically it keeps in the Winamp tradition
i haven't really found a good osx replacement, especially because of the annoying syncing thing
snow leopard ruined a lot of it by requiring the media buttons open iTunes
Also annoying is that VLC listens to them. So if I forget randomly, VLC stops and iTunes starts.
I remember that, ha
at one point we considered making django 1.0 actually 2.0 and retconning .96 to be 1.0
@leah ha, ha, yeah
he was completely, insanely anti-version # inflation
Puppet went from 0.25 to 2.6 after realizing they blew *way* past what should have been 1.0.
seems super funny in retrospect
my mom's company took sixteen years to go from 4.0 to 4.5
ten of those years were spent going from 4.0 to 4.1
my mom's programmer drove her crazy.. he would like double the number of features
Imagine installing Django 2.0, haha
Yeah, totally
@djchall were there steps in between?
but only increment the software from 4.0A to 4.0B

@justinlilly reminded me of winamp, too. However, firefox's dev team have been moving as fast as their v3.x so they NEED to speed things up. Plus, they have really suffered from the "one more feature" symptom with FF4.
Think Chrome version numbers are rather redundant, it's only appealing when you actually have to update manually
